abstract.text: Manage and load your app’s Metal shaders.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A Metal library represents a collection of one or more shaders. Xcode creates a library from the shader source files in a project, a Metal intermediate representation (IR) file, or a binary archive file. You can also create IR files from Metal source code by running the Metal compiler in a command-line environment.
Apps create the default library instance by calling a Metal device’s
method. The default library contains all the shaders from a project’s shader source files, which Xcode compiles at build time. Apps create additional libraries by passing an IR file to an
method or one of its sibling methods. The device can also create a library directly from source code by passing it as a string to the
You can apply a shader from a library to a pipeline state’s entry point, such as the
property for a compute pass. Start by retrieving an
instance from a library, which is a reference to the library’s shader, by calling its

method or a sibling method. Then set the function instance to the appropriate property of a pipeline descriptor. For example, an app can retrieve a vertex stage’s entry point shader from a library and assign it to the
Dynamic libraries are a collection of other shaders, typically utility functions, that support the entry point shaders for a pipeline state. To create a dynamic library, pass an
method, or pass a file URL to

. Add a dynamic library to a pipeline state by including it in an array of a pipeline descriptor’s preloaded libraries property. For example, if a vertex shader calls a shader in a dynamic library, directly or indirectly, add that dynamic library to the
property’s array. You can also build dynamic libraries with the Metal compiler in Terminal.

Binary archives are precompiled static libraries for specific GPU architectures that allow you to avoid the cost of runtime shader compilation. Because Metal automatically builds and caches shaders on the device running an app, use binary archives as part of your distributed app, or deliver them through content updates. See
for more information on how to build and distribute binary archives for any device that supports Metal.

abstract.text: Find and address performance bottlenecks using the Metal debugger.
Find the cause of your bugs by watching variables change as you step through your source code in the debugger.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Stepping through code and inspecting variables to isolate bugs

abstract.text: Render advanced 3D graphics and compute data in parallel with graphics processors.
Information about an argument of a graphics or compute function.
Function access restrictions to argument data in the shading language code.
The resource type for an argument of a function.
A description of an array.
An object that describes an attribute defined in the stage-in argument for a shader.
A convenience type alias for an autoreleased argument instance.
A convenience type alias for an autoreleased compute pipeline reflection object.
A convenience type alias for an autoreleased pipeline reflection instance.
A container for pipeline state descriptors and their associated compiled shader code.
Compilation settings for a Metal shader library.
The compute kernel the pipeline calls.
Information about the arguments of a compute function.
The types of GPU functions, including shaders and compute kernels.
The main Metal interface to a GPU that apps use to draw graphics and run computations in parallel.
Creates a Metal library instance that contains the functions from your app’s default Metal library.
Creates a Metal dynamic library instance from a Metal library instance.
Creates a Metal dynamic library instance that contains the functions in the Metal library file at a URL.
Creates a Metal library instance that contains the functions in the Metal library file at a URL.
Synchronously creates a Metal library instance by compiling the functions in a source string.
A dynamically linkable representation of compiled shader code for a specific Metal device object.
An object that represents a public shader function in a Metal library.
A constant that specializes the behavior of a shader.
A set of constant values that specialize a graphics or compute function.
A description of a function object to create.
An object representing a function that you can add to a visible function table.
A protocol to identify types that customize how the Metal compiler stitches a function together.
An attribute to specify that Metal needs to inline all of the function calls when generating the stitched function.
A call graph node that describes a function call and its inputs.
A description of a new stitched function.
A call graph node that describes an input to the call graph.
A protocol to identify call graph nodes.
A description of an intersection function that performs an intersection test.
A table of intersection functions that Metal calls to perform ray-tracing intersection tests.
A specification of how to create an intersection function table.
Metal shading language versions.
A collection of Metal shader functions.
Creates an object that represents a shader function in the library.
Metal errors related to libraries.
Error codes for Metal library errors.
The error domain for Metal libraries.
The optimization options for the Metal compiler.
A set of options for Metal library types.
A container for shader log messages.
An interface that represents a log state configuration.
A description of a pointer.
An argument of options you pass to a GPU device to get a render pipeline state.
The vertex function the pipeline calls to process vertices.
Information about the arguments of a graphics function.
A description of a new library of procedurally generated functions.
An object that provides information about a field in a structure.
A description of a structure.
A description of a texture.
A description of a data type.
An object that represents an attribute of a vertex function.
A table of shader functions visible to your app that you can pass into compute commands to customize the behavior of a shader.
A specification of how to create a visible function table.
Write your Metal pipeline states to a binary archive at app runtime, and build binaries for any supported GPU.

doc://com.apple.metal/documentation/Meta.title: Creating Binary Archives from Device-Built Pipeline State Objects

abstract.text: Define custom shader behavior at runtime by creating functions from existing ones and preferentially linking to others in a dynamic library.

doc://com.apple.metal/documentation/Meta.title: Customizing shaders using function pointers and stitching

abstract.text: Print debugging messages that a shader generates using shader logging.
Distribute precompiled GPU-specific binaries as part of your app to avoid runtime compilation of Metal shaders.
Create a single Metal library containing reusable code to reduce library size and avoid repeated shader compilation at runtime.
Compile and manage Metal libraries from the command line.
Create static and dynamic shader libraries, and binary shader archives.
Create pipelines for different levels of detail from a common shader source.
